EU to loan €90 billion to Ukraine while delaying Mercosur deal
byline: By Virginie Malingre (Brussels, Europe bureau) and Philippe Jacqué (Brussels, Europe bureau)
subhed: The aid allocated to Kyiv will take the form of a zero-interest loan, after the bloc failed to agree on using frozen Russian assets. Meanwhile, the free trade agreement with the South American Mercosur trade bloc was postponed to January, as Italy joined France in blocking it.

title: French lawmakers fail to agree on state budget bill
Putin says Russian troops 'are advancing along the entire line of contact' in Ukraine
Louvre staff call off strike and museum to open 'as normal,' unions say
byline: Le Monde with AP and AFP
subhed: Union leaders on Friday said staff at the Paris museum had voted against another day of stoppages, but warned of future industrial action because of 'insufficient progress' in talks with management and the Culture Ministry.

title: French anesthetist sentenced to life in prison: 'We cannot bring back our loved ones, but at least there is a semblance of justice'
subhed: A criminal court in eastern France found Frédéric Péchier guilty of 30 poisonings: 12 murders and 18 attempted murders. His sentence includes a 22-year period during which he is ineligible for parole and a permanent ban from practicing medicine. His lawyer announced he will appeal the verdict.

title: Astoria, Zohran Mamdani's working-class New York
subhed: The victory of New York City's new mayor on November 4 was also a victory for his Queens neighborhood, Astoria, which he made the focus of his campaign. This cosmopolitan district, plagued by economic difficulties, wants to be a beacon of hope in Trump's America.

title: Trump dogged by cost of living crisis and Republican revolt
subhed: The US president tried to defuse Americans' dissatisfaction with the economy in a televised address on Wednesday. He continued to blame Joe Biden, but struggled to grasp the extent of the issue – provoking tensions within his own party.

'It is easier to flatter the people than to serve. Therein lies the last obstacle to an RN victory in 2027'
subhed: Populism has never been stronger in France, but there is a crucial difference between flattering the people and serving them, and the Rassemblement National is currently stumbling on that divide, writes Le Monde columnist Françoise Fressoz.

title: A French farmer's distress: 'I found the first dead cow when I went to the pasture'
subhed: Near Benque, a village an hour from Toulouse, farmer Christian Lasserre discovered three carcasses on Saturday. He fears a new outbreak of lumpy skin disease and the culling of the entire herd.

title: In Paris, the number of homeless living in outdoor camps continues to rise
subhed: Outreach teams counted 663 tents in the main encampment areas of the French capital at the end of November, representing between 985 and 1,723 people. The rise is driven by a reduction in available shelter spaces and tighter restrictions on residency permits.
